quizzes.question: Transitions between scenes are called...
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Navigation[/h1]

The data display as expected; now we need to provide for navigation from the items list to the item scene. The transitions between app scenes are called [b]segues[/b].
A [b]navigation controller[/b] manages transitions backward and forward through a series of view controllers. The set of view controllers managed by a particular navigation controller is called its [b]navigation stack[/b]. 
Open [i]Main.storyboard[/i].
Select the table view controller by clicking on its scene dock. [img id="1041" width="100%"] 
With the table view controller selected, choose[b] Editor > Embed In > Navigation Controller[/b].
Xcode now adds a new navigation controller to your storyboard, sets its storyboard entry point, and establishes a relationship between the new navigation controller and your existing table view controller. [img id="1042" width="100%"] 
On the canvas, the icon that connects the controllers indicates the root view controller relationship.
You might notice that your table view now has a bar at the top. This is a navigation bar. [img id="1043" width="60%"]
[note]Every controller on the navigation stack has its navigation bar, which can contain controls for backward and forward navigation.[/note]

quizzes.question: The item representing a button on the navigation bar is called the...
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Configure the Navigation Bar [/h1]

To add a title, double-click the navigation bar in the items list scene. [img id="1044" width="100%"] 
Enter a title and press Return.
In the [b]Object library[/b], find a [b]Bar Button Item[/b] object.
Drag a [b]Bar Button Item[/b] object from the list to the far right of the navigation bar.
A button called [b]Item [/b]appears where you dragged the bar button item. [img id="1046" width="100%"] 
Select the bar button item and open the [b]Attributes inspector[/b], where you'll choose [b]Add [/b]from the pop-up menu next to the[b] System Item[/b] option.
The button will change to an Add button (+). [img id="1045" width="100%"][note]The varying choices for the [b]System Item[/b] property can be used to change the appearance of the button.[/note]

quizzes.question: The type of the transition is chosen from...
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Configuring Navigation[/h1]

To have the Add button (+) bring up the item scene, we need to trigger a [b]segue [/b](or [b]transition[/b]) to that scene.
On the canvas, select the Add button (+) and [b]Control-drag [/b]from the button to the item scene.[img id="1047" width="50%"] 
A shortcut menu with the title [b]Action Segue[/b] appears in the location where the drag ended. [img id="1048" width="50%"] 
The [b]Action Segue[/b] menu allows you to choose what type of segue to use when transitioning.
Choose [b]show [/b]from the Action Segue menu.
Run your app. You can click the [b]Add button [/b]and navigate to the item scene from the items list scene. Because you're using a navigation controller with a show segue, the backward navigation is handled for you, and a [b]back button[/b] automatically appears in the scene. [img id="1049" width="60%"] 
We have also removed the [b]Save Item[/b] button from the scene; we'll add the [b]Save [/b]and [b]Cancel [/b]button to the navigation.
[note]You can change the transition by choosing the segue and modifying the [b]Segue [/b]option in the Attributes inspector.
To identify the segue, type [b]AddItem [/b]in the [b]Identifier [/b]field in the Attributes inspector.[/note]

quizzes.question: You can change the appearance of the Bar Button Items.
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Configuring Navigation[/h1]

To add the "New Item" scene to the navigation, simply repeat the steps you used for the items list scene when embedding it in a Navigation Controller. Give it a title and add two Bar Button Items, selecting [b]Cancel[/b] and [b]Save [/b]as the [b]System Item[/b] in Attribute inspector.
Run the app. When you click the [b]Add [/b]button from the items list, you should see this: [img id="1050" width="70%"] 
[note]The buttons haven't been linked to any actions yet, so they need to be configured for actions.[/note]
We've changed a few of the items on the view, so we need to update the layout of the stack view. In the "New Item" scene, select the stack view. 
On the bottom right of the canvas, open the [b]Resolve Auto Layout Issues[/b] menu. [img id="1051" width="60%"] 
Under Selected Views, choose [b]Update Constraints[/b].
[note]The elements remain in their original positions, but the stack view is now pinned to the navigation bar, instead of to the top margin of the view.[/note]
